bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, [November 2, 1948]

div1.p: Truby discusses photographs of Cuba. He includes one of his own drawings of the 8th Infantry Camp at La Punta.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, [November 2, 1948]
div1.opener:
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco 18, California
Dear Dr Hench-
div1.p:
Your “Luftpost” post card dated
Nov 8 from Copenhagen was delivered
here in 3 days. What a wonderful time
you & Mrs Hench have had. Will look forward
to hearing about some of the high spots if
you really come to S.F. as you intimated
you might. That would be grand and
I hope it works out that way.

I enjoyed the Cuban pictures. All of
them were typical and similar to ones that
we were all taking when we were there.
Three of them were of particular interest to
me viz. two of La Punta and one of Gen. Lee's
staff. I made notes on those three for you
which will I think interest you very much.

The pictures came to me first so I sent them
on to Gen. Kean and he has just written me
that they are now on the way to you at Rochester
by express. I think the photo, of Gen. Lee & staff
should go into your book. It looks like a Civil
War outfit and the heavy blue uniforms in Cuba
show how unprepared we were 50 yrs ago for
War. Kean knows most of the names of those in the photo
AC
Tr
I knew Cols. Mans. & Michie. Mans was
the Chief Surgeon whom Kean relieved shortly
after the picture was taken.

The picture showing the west side of the old
stone fort at La Punta and the other one
showing the site of my regimental hospital &
my room in the Engineer's Bldg, are very fine
and most interesting to me. I do hope you can
make have copies made of those 3 photos.
My drawings & notes will make things clear
to you I think. So please don't send the
photos. back to Nebraska until you see the
remarks Kean & I have made.

I hope Mrs. Hench was able to get away
from Paris without waiting for the strike to
end. Things must have been most hectiehectic
in Paris for a time.

We have been going along on an even
Keel here. Just now Mrs. T. & Elizabeth are
busy getting off their Christmas packages and
I lend a hand when necessary. I have been
very well, none of the little things to bother me
that were constantly coming up when I first
became ill. I cured them all myself after
my medical advisers failed.

You wrote that you expected to be back home
about Dec. 17th. I am getting this off early so
that it will be there when you arrive.

Mrs Truby, Elizabeth & I join in wishing you
and Mrs. Hench and your children a Merry
Christmas & Happy New Year.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, [November 2, 1948]
div1.p:
8th Infantry camp at La Punta
not 10th Inf as stated on the photo. See p24 my book
(Over) XCamara AET

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, [November 2, 1948]
div1.p:
This is a splendid' photo and
you should have copies made. I would
like a copy & will be glad to pay
for it. It shows my tent on the parapet
and my corner room in the long Spanish.
Engineer's building.

This building was
about 100 yds long
with short wings at
each end as shown
in this sketch.

Windows in my
corner room.
no 1 faced South
no 2. East.
This was the 8th Infantry Camp
not 10th Inf as stated on the 'photo
The name of the monument in the
Punta park I have forgotten.

See pictures in my book p. 18, 19,
20, 21, 42.
